review_title: Great Community Environment with Lots of Growth Potential
pros: Great working environment that focuses on teamwork. For the most part, employees seem to pride themselves on patient-centered care; they take the mission to heart and truly want to aid patients and their families in whatever way possible. Community involvement is encouraged. Another great aspect is growth from within. It seems like managers would rather grow and promote employees who are interested in growing before considering outside candidates. It really is a community.  The benefits are decent, but they do start day 1 which is nice. Another great benefit is discounted membership to the Vidant Wellness Center. It is the first gym that I've been a member of where I didn't have to wait for equipment, even during the peak 5pm-8pm hours. It's also really clean. The employee pharmacy is awesome! Generics are often 5 dollars or less. They also have bandaids, cough drops, diapers, etc. for crazy low prices.
cons: It really is a community, therefore there are negative employees and departments and managers that don't embrace the mission. However, there is new leadership and they seem to be making positive changes. Parking is an issue, you will get ticketed and booted and it will be expensive if you park outside of your designated area. Your designated area will be far from the hospital unless you work nights or are a physician or PA. And while the cafeteria has great options, it is very crowded from 12-1.

review_title: Vidant Medical Center - Staff Nurse II
job_title: Staff Nurse II in Greenville, NC
pros: Well, it's an academic medical center, they're fundamentally the same  no matter where you are. I can't imagine working at one of the smaller hospitals in the area, which are all also owned by Vidant. Most of the staff are locals and feel a connection to the area. Pay is ok considering the low cost of living, middle class housing can be had for 125,000 in Greenville and under 6 figures outside of it. Spaces everywhere, if you want to step into the ICU or Cath lab they'll take you.
cons: Travelers frequently say we're getting used. Its a difficult area to attract people too, without a lot of cultural opportunities. Perpetual short staffing but hey, that's nursing everywhere as far as I can tell. Patient population is very poor, under educated, with few options for definitive treatment. Recent moves towards increasing patient load have little bearing on reality. Current CEO is an improvement over the last but healthcare as a whole is moving towards hard choices, especially in areas like Eastern NC with a high medicaid/ medicare population.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Greenville, NC
pros: Lots of money for technology. Spending millions of dollars on technology. Very nice employees who are trying to do the right things by the company.
cons: Millions spent on technology and only good training spent on people who work on Healthspan. They force people out because they don't got up to date skills and hire all their friends from their old company. CIO believes any bad stuff about us and wants only people who tell her yes. We lost great bosses because she didn't like him and he retired. Nearly everybody left us and was replaced with a director or other manager but no people to do work so we pay outsiders to do it who teaching us nothing. It makes me feel very sad for us. Everyone is afraid the CIO and is moving all of technology to Raleigh to be in with other hospitals.

pros: A pay check and a few friendly people.
cons:
They treat the hard working people like absolute garbage. 
Also when a better shift comes around and the person whose been there longer gets snubbed for it because they "dont have anyone to replace you" but fill the better time position to the newest person is just about the biggest slap in the face. 
They also don't even try to protect you and won't even follow their rules! The head manager makes them but will still give the customer what they want even though they train you to say no sorry you only get this said amount. They love to make you look like a jerk in front of other people. 
Do not get the insurance if you are only part time. You will be paying almost 200 a check.
Also don't expect to get uniforms. They say they will purchase them for you but they don't come. I waited seven months and nothing except pants with the wrong girls name in them.

pros: Health benefits, stable employer and a good place to gain experience.
cons: Underpaid (largest hospital in the area that brings in millions of dollars, but they do NOT pay lab technicians a fair wage) overworked (ALWAYS short staffed), lazy co-workers, (management knows certain employees net surf, have excessive personal calls and take an extra long lunches and do NOTHING about it.  AMAZING!!) . Lastly, in my 20+ career, I have never worked with a more gossipy (smile in your face and talk about you behind your back. no matter how nice and helpful you try to be, group of people.)  No significant pay raises based upon solid good work performance.

review_title: What your making the day you start is what you will make in 30 years
pros:
Your in the A/C 90% of the time
PTO
401k
Health

You can go up to an pent house and sleep all day and or play guitar while everyone else has to do your work for you.
cons:
The company doesn't care about its employees.

They would rather pay more for inexperienced person to come work for them rather than if you're making a transfer between departments they'll give you the bare minimum and start the other guy off making more and he doesn't know anything about the company.

Light bulb changers who sit in the shop all day make more than some one who does that person's job for them.

review_title: Top Three In Greenville, North Carolina
pros:
1. Excellent benefits
2. Above market rate compensation
3. Centrally located in rapidly growing mid size city
4. Parking 
5. Employee clinic, wellness center, and employee pharmacy
cons:
1. One of only 3 biggest employers in the City; therefore, management is not accountable for "BAD" behavior. 
2. Favoritism: all levels of management have select individuals that are groomed, trained and exposed to growth.  Exclusion: those who are not favored don't get invited to training, meetings, are the last to know of any implementations. Ageism: other than mid to upper management those  who are favored, trained and given opportunity for growth are under 40 "not of color". Few key positions are held by minority women and 0.01%  by minority men.
4. Leadership is authoritative, rude, and borderline mean.
5. High level of stressed out team members.

review_title: Overall learning experience; micromanaged, negative environment.
pros: Began as a very positive experience. Educational opportunities onsite; learning opportunities are everywhere. Scheduling requests are usually honored, but recent policy changes prevent co-workers from switching shifts if needed. Many resources and decent benefits, and everyday brings something new.
cons: Management provides little to no staff support; many supervisors are too job-scared to stand up for what is morally correct. Meetings are held constantly to discuss issues, yet it seems nothing is ever fixed. Leadership fails to see the big picture while micromanaging to no end. Look at the recent turn-over and retention rate. Work-life balance is poor; workplace environment and employee moral has continued to worsen.

review_title: CIO is Tough, Fair and Loyal First to Our Patients
pros:
-CIO/CTO combination has dug us out of a gigantic hole with training, accountability, financial and project forecasting, and management. 
-Weeded out several people who were cancers within the departments they led, many hold-overs from when the hospital was a county run entity.
-Focused directly on employee engagement and communication with regular all staff meetings, communications and status of corporate initiatives. 
-Raised compensation in areas where we had no chance of attracting top talent in key areas unless leadership went to bat to fix it.
-Created definitive job families and levels within them so employees have a clear road map for their self-development and career growth. 
-Stopped giving employee reviews that were based upon how well you were liked by your manager and not on what you have achieved. 
-Invested in key areas to improve technology infrastructure instead of focusing purely on expanding the footprint of the EMR (with no accounting for long term impact or cost)
cons:
-Currently in an enormous bubble of deployments, upgrades, and architecture changes that has caused many to feel overwhelmed, or that the rush will never end.
-Understaffed for amount of work, which could put systems at risk of not being fully leveraged, or failure. (However, Vidant Health is in 300% better position currently than when the CIO started, despite the current stress on staff.)
-Too many Chiefs and not enough Indians. This is currently looked upon by staff as unwillingness of VPs and C-level staff to work with line level employees. (This has leveled, and all management from Managers to Directors, are working people who have direct client facing issue level communications and planning with their customers or line-level employees)

review_title: Good place to learn and gain experience.
pros: Worked with some awesome people. Large hospital, so great opportunity to learn a lot.
cons: Has some upper management issues. Pay not very competitive with other level I trauma centers in the same area.

pros: Facility is nice in terms of cleanliness and decor. There are some very caring and knowledgeable staff who work really hard here!
cons: Small upper  management team covers huge business lines. Often do not want to train others for fear they might lose income. They hire externally. Promised no more contract nurses but preferred to send loyal seasoned staff away. Treat employees like peons.

pros: It's just a Job and that's too bad.  Morale is so low in my department and no one cares. Countless people have left. No One Cares!!!!!
cons:
Unqualified Management in positions that they do not qualify for. Read this as favoritism. 
Unresponsive HR in general. Grievances go nowhere. 
What exactly is the IS turnover rate? In 5 years I can't think of a leadership member who has lasted longer than 2 years. Wow. What a record. Is that the hiring bonus threshold or what? As if that is not bad enough HR does nothing to correct it. Just look the other way.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Greenville, NC
pros: Excellent company and community to work in. Greenville, NC has such a tight community that supports ECU to the fullest and the pride in the college and their sport teams was amazing. Also, the support from the Law enforcement , fire & EMS with the Emergency Dept. staff was unlike any other I have experienced. Most all staff was very willing to teach and educate.
cons: It is a large organization which does take away from the personal fee that it started with as PCMH

pros: Benefits are good and they are always looking to imprve them. Job Security - Hospital is growing and is the largest employer in Pitt County.
cons: Long hours are required to get job done. Unqualified people are promoted and qualified people are not. PCMH has VPs who have no job responsibilities and they should be let go. The staff knows which VPs these are and by keeping them it just proves to staff that Senior Management cannot step up to the plate and get rid of unnecessary positions.

pros: Decent benefits, affordable insurance (when full-time), FMLA offered when appropriate, decent scheduling depending on what department you are working in.
cons: I worked in a department that was not a critical department, so, if we were short staffed, it didn't affect the hospital or patient care, just my department. Was continually bad mouthed by my coworkers for not coming into work if I was sick (even with a doctor's note and clear symptoms of a sickness), bad mouthed for missing/being late/leaving early for family emergencies (family member woke up and COULDNT SEE, and I was the only person available to take them to the doctor, unless I called 911, and was LATE: didn't miss work, just late, and was still talked about), or not coming in because of bad weather (we had about 20 employees, myself included. A fellow coworker and myself were the only employees who lived an hour away: everyone else was 20 mins or less. It snowed and iced, and yet we were complained about because we didn't come into work. I was told 'well the roads aren't bad here.' Well, it was going to take me 2 & 1/2 hours to get 'there' whereas my road was one huge sheet of ice, as was the other girl who lived an hour away.

pros: Great staff who care about patient care and safety
cons:
Long hours, lack of empowerment,  and  a punitive environment contribute to the toxic environment there.   Poor communication throughout the enterprise.
The Peter Principle is alive and well.

review_title: Excellent hospital! Great  interdisciplinary team to work with as well as phenomenal fellow nurses to work with!
job_title: Level I Trauma/ER RN in Greenville, NC
pros: The best healthcare facility I've worked at. Gained so much experience and learned so much plus mastered many important skills.
cons: Need to work hard, stay focused and be very skilled at performing skills and providing the best care to patients. Taught me great discipline and organization. Loved it!

review_title: Great place to practice nursing for 1 year and then move on to better avenues of nursing advancement.
job_title: RN, Staff Nurse in Greenville, NC
pros: Great benefits and various work enviroments. choose carefully and make sure you talk to staff as to their likes of the department you are interviewing  for a position.
cons: Management manages only from the office.

pros: If you're a nurse you have plenty of autonomy. Largest employer that is close to the beach. Great college in the city.
cons: If you're in any other field other than healthcare worker such as IT, Accountant, etc...etc....there's not enough jobs to move up. Over-saturated area for anything other than direct healthcare workers.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Technologist in Greenville, NC
pros: Flexibility is awesome we are able to change a schedule change hours during the day we're able to attend the family emergencies without any headache
cons: Physical demands is too much for the pay and expectation of a job.send a text or not appreciated for the skills and ability that have within your job and it's requirements.

review_title: It has been a good experience.  My director is a really nice guy who cares about the department.
pros: Really good benefits.  Work family balance. Management helpful most of the time but like any other place of employment  some things slip through the cracks.
cons: Hard to advance forward or transfer to  another department. Sometimes management forget how hard it can be to be seen and heard.

review_title: Not for a person with a brain.
pros: slow pace, friendly people (at least to your face), fexible schedules, you dont have to keep uptodate on current things
cons: sr. management claims to want to improve or grow, but they strongly fight against new ideas or those that dont agree with their outdated ways, if youre good at kissing butts youll do fine, the miracle is that they still provide fairly average care

pros: VMC is an academic, level III trauma center that is also the only community hospital.  Therefore, we see all comers, creating a unique learning and practicing environment.
cons: All the aspects of complexity that make the hospital a unique learning environment also can make it a bureauocratic jungle.  Change and progress seem painfully slow.

review_title: Very low pay compared to almost anywhere else
job_title: Sterile Processing Supervisor in Greenville, NC
pros: Strong leadership team that is very knowledgeable
cons: Some of the lowest pay in North Carolina. Rarely does the HR department follow through same day, next day, or even same week to send documents, resolve issues, or just to get a return phone call.  Usually issues brought to HR require escalation to upper management to resolve issue. Seems to be a lot of intra-departmental squabbling. High turnover.

review_title: Way too many managers and non-clinical professional staff
pros: Friendly atmosphere and free parking (in timbuk tu)
cons: Non-competetive pay, top heavy in management, 20 minute parking-to-floor trip. Expensive health insurance for families.

review_title: Not for a long term career

pros: It is a good place to start when you are right out of school and still trying to gain work experience.
cons: The pay is not competitive and the health benefits are ridiculously expensive. Management micromanages staff. And while there are a few staff who are genuinely nice, majority are "fake nice", narrow minded, and are not culturally competent.

cons: Shortage of nurses on every floor. Many flex shifts were required every pay period. Pay was mediocre, but as a new grad it was expected.
